author.affiliation: California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125

abstract.p: We propose a mechanism for stabilizing the size of the extra dimension in the Randall-Sundrum scenario. The potential for the modulus field that sets the size of the fifth dimension is generated by a bulk scalar with quartic interactions localized on the two 3-branes. The minimum of this potential yields a compactification scale that solves the hierarchy problem without fine tuning of parameters.

body.p: The Standard Model for strong, weak, and electromagnetic interactions based on the gauge group S⁢U⁢(3)×S⁢U⁢(2)×U⁢(1)𝑆𝑈3𝑆𝑈2𝑈1 has been extremely succesful in accounting for experimental observations. However, it has several unattractive features that suggest new physics beyond that incorporated in this model. One of these is the gauge hierarchy problem, which refers to the vast disparity between the weak scale and the Planck scale. In the context of the minimal Standard Model, this hierarchy of scales is unnatural since it requires a fine tuning order by order in perturbation theory. A number of extensions have been proposed to solve the hierarchy problem, notably technicolor(1) (or dynamical symmetry breaking) and low energy supersymmetry(2).

Recently, it has been suggested that large compactified extra dimensions may provide an alternative solution to the hierarchy problem(3). In these models, the observed Planck mass MP⁢lsubscript𝑀𝑃𝑙 is related to M,𝑀 the fundamental mass scale of the theory, by MP⁢l2=Mn+2⁢Vn,superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑃𝑙2superscript𝑀𝑛2subscript𝑉𝑛 where Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛 is the volume of the additional compactified dimensions. If Vnsubscript𝑉𝑛 is large enough, M𝑀 can be of the order of the weak scale. Unfortunately, unless there are several large extra dimensions, a new hierarchy is introduced between the compactification scale, μc=Vn-1/n,subscript𝜇𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑉𝑛1𝑛 and M.𝑀

Randall and Sundrum (4) have proposed a higher dimensional scenario to solve the hierachy problem that does not require large extra dimensions. This model consists of a spacetime with a single S1/Z2superscript𝑆1subscript𝑍2 orbifold extra dimension. Three-branes with opposite tensions reside at the orbifold fixed points and together with a finely tuned cosmological constant serve as sources for five-dimensional gravity. The resulting spacetime metric contains a redshift factor which depends exponentially on the radius rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 of the compactified dimension:

where k𝑘 is a parameter which is assumed to be of order M𝑀, xμsuperscript𝑥𝜇 are Lorentz coordinates on the four-dimensional surfaces of constant ϕitalic-ϕ, and -π≤ϕ≤π𝜋italic-ϕ𝜋 with (x,ϕ)𝑥italic-ϕ and (x,-ϕ)𝑥italic-ϕ identified. The two 3-branes are located at ϕ=0italic-ϕ0 and ϕ=π.italic-ϕ𝜋 A similar scenario to the one described in ref. (4) is that of Horava and Witten (5), which arises within the context of M𝑀-theory. Supergravity solutions similar to Eq. (1) are presented in ref. (6). In ref. (7), it is shown how this model may be obtained from string theory compactifications.
The non-factorizable geometry of Eq. (1) has several important consequences. For instance, the four-dimensional Planck mass is given in terms of the fundamental scale M𝑀 by

so that, even for large k⁢rc,𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐MP⁢lsubscript𝑀𝑃𝑙 is of order M.𝑀 Because of the exponential factor in the spacetime metric, a field confined to the 3-brane at ϕ=πitalic-ϕ𝜋 with mass parameter m0subscript𝑚0 will have physical mass m0⁢e-k⁢rc⁢πsubscript𝑚0superscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐𝜋 and for k⁢rc𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐 around 12, the weak scale is dynamically generated from a fundamental scale M𝑀 which is on the order of the Planck mass. Furthermore, Kaluza-Klein gravitational modes have TeV scale mass splittings and couplings(8). Similarly, a bulk field with mass on the order of M𝑀 has low-lying Kaluza-Klein excitations that reside primarily near ϕ=πitalic-ϕ𝜋 and hence, from a four-dimensional perspective, have masses on the order of the weak scale (9).

In the scenario presented in ref. (4), rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 is associated with the vacuum expectation value of a massless four-dimensional scalar field. This modulus field has zero potential and consequently rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 is not determined by the dynamics of the model. For this scenario to be relevant, it is necessary to find a mechanism for generating a potential to stabilize the value of rc.subscript𝑟𝑐 Here we show that such a potential can arise classically from the presence of a bulk scalar with interaction terms that are localized to the two 3-branes
Other proposals for stabilizing the rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 modulus can be found in ref. (10).. The minimum of this potential can be arranged to yield a value of k⁢rc∼10similar-to𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐10 without fine tuning of parameters.

With ln⁡(vh/vv)subscript𝑣ℎsubscript𝑣𝑣 of order unity, we only need m2/k2superscript𝑚2superscript𝑘2 of order 1/10110 to get k⁢rc∼10.similar-to𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐10 Clearly, no extreme fine tuning of parameters is required to get the right magnitude for k⁢rc.𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐 For instance, taking vh/vv=1.5subscript𝑣ℎsubscript𝑣𝑣1.5 and m/k=0.2𝑚𝑘0.2 yields k⁢rc≃12.similar-to-or-equals𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐12
The stress tensor for the scalar field can be written as TsA⁢B=TkA⁢B+TmA⁢B,subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝐴𝐵𝑠subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝐴𝐵𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑇𝐴𝐵𝑚 where for large k⁢rc𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐:

As long as vh2/M3superscriptsubscript𝑣ℎ2superscript𝑀3 and vv2/M3superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑣2superscript𝑀3 are small, TsA⁢Bsubscriptsuperscript𝑇𝐴𝐵𝑠 can be neglected in comparison to the stress tensor induced by the bulk cosmological constant. It is therefore safe to ignore the influence of the scalar field on the background geometry for the computation of V⁢(rc)𝑉subscript𝑟𝑐. A similar criterion ensures that the stress tensor induced by the bulk cosmological constant is dominant for k⁢rc∼1.similar-to𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐1

One might worry that the validity of Eq. (13) and Eq. (14) requires unnaturally large values of λhsubscript𝜆ℎ and λvsubscript𝜆𝑣. We will check that this is not the case by computing the leading 1/λ1𝜆 correction to the potential. To obtain this correction, we linearize Eq. (9) and Eq. (10) about the large λ𝜆 solution. Neglecting terms of order ϵitalic-ϵ, the VEVs are shifted by

This has the same form as the leading ϵ→0→italic-ϵ0 behavior of Eq. (13) and therefore does not significantly affect the location of the minimum.
Note that the forms of the potentials in Eq. (13) and Eq. (23) are only valid for large k⁢rc𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐. For small k⁢rc𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐, the potential becomes

In the scenario of Randall and Sundrum, the action is the sum of the five-dimensional Einstein-Hilbert action plus world-volume actions for the 3-branes:

For Eq. (1) to be a solution of the field equations that follow from Eq. (26), one must arrange Vh=-Vv=24⁢M3⁢k,subscript𝑉ℎsubscript𝑉𝑣24superscript𝑀3𝑘 where Λ=-24⁢M3⁢k2Λ24superscript𝑀3superscript𝑘2. This amounts to having a vanishing four-dimensional cosmological constant plus an additional fine tuning which causes the rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 potential to vanish. However, imagine perturbing the 3-brane tensions by small amounts
It has been noted that given the action in Eq. (26), changes in the relation between the brane tensions and the bulk cosmological constant result in bent brane solutions(11). It is possible that there are higher dimension induced curvature terms in the brane actions that make it energetically favorable for them to stay flat. For Vh=-Vv=24⁢M3⁢k,subscript𝑉ℎsubscript𝑉𝑣24superscript𝑀3𝑘 Eq. (1) remains a solution to the field equations in the presence of such terms.:
As long as |δ⁢Vh|𝛿subscript𝑉ℎ and |δ⁢Vv|𝛿subscript𝑉𝑣 are small compared to -Λ/k,Λ𝑘 these shifts in the brane tensions induce the following potential for rcsubscript𝑟𝑐

For δ⁢Vv𝛿subscript𝑉𝑣 small, the sum of potentials VΦ⁢(rc)+VΛ⁢(rc)subscript𝑉Φsubscript𝑟𝑐subscript𝑉Λsubscript𝑟𝑐 has a minimum for large k⁢rc.𝑘subscript𝑟𝑐 The effective four-dimensional cosmological constant can be tuned to zero by adjusting the value of δ⁢Vh.𝛿subscript𝑉ℎ For δ⁢Vv<k⁢ϵ⁢vv2𝛿subscript𝑉𝑣𝑘italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑣2 the minimum is global, while for δ⁢Vv>k⁢ϵ⁢vv2𝛿subscript𝑉𝑣𝑘italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑣2 the minimum is a false vacuum since rc→∞→subscript𝑟𝑐 is a configuration of lower energy.

We have seen that a bulk scalar with a ϕitalic-ϕ-dependent VEV can generate a potential to stabilize rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 without having to fine tune the parameters of the model (there is still one fine tuning associated with the four-dimensional cosmological constant, however). This mechanism for stabilizing rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 is a reasonably generic effect caused by the presence of a ϕitalic-ϕ-dependent vacuum bulk field configuration. It may be worthwile to work out other features of the specific toy model presented here, such as the back reaction of the scalar field and shifts of the brane tensions on the spacetime geometry. Also, the use of the large λ𝜆 limit was purely for convenience and the finite λ𝜆 case could be considered.

With rcsubscript𝑟𝑐 stabilized, the cosmology associated with this scenario should be standard for temperatures below the weak scale. However, for temperatures above this scale, it will be different (see ref. (12)) from the usual Friedmann cosmology.

The scenario presented in ref. (4) represents an attractive solution to the hierarchy puzzle. However, it also has some features that are less appealing than the Standard Model with minimal particle content. In this scenario, higher dimension operators are suppressed by the weak scale and unlike the Standard Model, where the suppression can be by powers of the GUT scale, there is no explanation for the smallness of neutrino masses and the long proton lifetime based simply on dimensional analysis.
We thank R. Sundrum for several useful conversations. This work was supported in part by the Department of Energy under grant number DE-FG03-92-ER 40701.
